As I mentioned in a comment to Lewis, this puzzle was very similar to one on January 22, 2023 by Garrett Chalpin, which I just happened to do today right before starting this one.  The theme is almost the same except that the two parts of each answer can be homophones, and the added Ys can be homophones too. So you also get answers like NOSY BESTIE (knows best) and WHINY STORY (wine store). Today's puzzle must have been harder to construct than that one. 

The only section that tripped me up for a while was the NE where I had canDY COPY. That was before I realized that each phrase had to make sense as an expression without the Ys. I don't love the clue for that one since a GOODY is not necessarily sweet or even edible (thinking of goody bags given at birthday parties that can contain trinkets and little toys in addition to sweet treats.) I'm not saying it's wrong, but I would have omitted "sweet" and left it at "treat."
I suppose it's faithful to the TYLENOL ban, given then DEMEROL substitute being fielded.

Instead of pointing out an error, it said I had solved it!  And yes, I lost my streak in the process.  I'm a bit peeved, to say the least.

How wonderful that it solves to the legendary originator of the phrase. I hope everyone knows the story of ARCHIMEDES in his bathtub, discovering a way to distinguish pure gold from fake. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka_(word) Fun additional fact: "Heureka" is the present perfect (first person, singular) of the Greek verb "heuriskein", which means "to find", so that the shout simply means, "I have found [it]."

I was curious about the gamy vs gamey debate so I looked up both variants on the Google ngram viewer. Since 1800, in general "gamy" has been more commonly used, but very recently (after 2000) "gamey" has taken the lead. This corresponds well with my (age 58) impression of "gamy" being the "correct" spelling. Amok / amuck is similar, with "amuck" being more common from 1860 to the late 1940s, when "amok" gradually came into greater use. "Amok" took a commanding lead in the mid-1980s and now is by far the more common spelling.

I thought this was fine. I do wonder if it would have gone over better if it had fewer theme entries. Often I prefer a few clever theme entries to many, because the theme answers constrain the rest of the fill and make the rest of the puzzle less fun or satisfying. If the theme is entertaining enough, I suppose it justifies that sacrifice, but when it's just mildly clever, maybe not so much. @NH A lot of people, especially older people (and I don't know if MB is an older person, but chances are that is the case, based on the nature of the comment) have a fossilized notion of what's correct and incorrect, based on what their fourth grade teacher taught them 30, 40, 50, 60 or 70 years ago. Language changes, and M-W is at the forefront of recognizing language change faster than other dictionaries. There are always citations given (8 in the case of "amuck"). And modern languages document usage (descriptivism) rather than lecture on so-called proper usage (prescriptivism). That's left to English professors and style guides that set a certain perceived "standard" of usage at a higher level. (The acceptable level for crosswords is simply that the word exists.) Google Ngram Viewer shows that although the less common variant, "amuck" is used about 1/4 as often as "amok," certainly a greater-than-zero number. The two ran neck-and-neck until the 70s, when "amok" became more prevalent. https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=amok%2Camuck&year_start=1800&year_end=2022&corpus=en&smoothing=3 The Daffy Duck cartoon short, "Duck Amuck," was released in 1953, so you could hardly say this usage is a trendy neologism that those darned kids came up with. In fact, another look at the Ngram shows that both forms existed 125 years ago, when the "amuck" spelling was actually more common. "Amuck" is also found in Cambridge, Collins and Britannica. So yes, lexicographers.
